@zliu41 for the last few days, there have been some timing related failures in Travis which pass on localhost. This patch is meant to address some of them.
The Travis failures were due to lack of tags. I added some automation in build.gradle to deal with that.

LGTM. The behavior you mentioned above was introduced as part of the efforts to fix a deadlock issue related to the use of `synchronized` around the `get` method in those classes. See #340 and #355. I didn't realize there's a `gobblin.metrics.notifications.timer` in each `MetricContext`, but a `Callable` should be used to load a value in case of a cache miss at the time to avoid creating temporary `MetricContext` instances.
LGTM.
Good find! By the way, you can use the method `buildStrict()` when building a `MetricContext` to throw an error on conflict instead of silently modifying the name.
LGTM
I see, yes good to know.

LGTM. Seems the build failed on Java 7 due to the following test failure. Maybe you can give a longer timeout to it in this PR:

```
Gradle test > gobblin.scheduler.JobConfigFileMonitorTest.testAddNewJobConfigFile FAILED
    java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException: Timeout waiting for condition '4 scheduled jobs'.
        at gobblin.testing.AssertWithBackoff.assertTrue(AssertWithBackoff.java:185)
        at gobblin.testing.AssertWithBackoff.assertTrue(AssertWithBackoff.java:134)
        at gobblin.testing.AssertWithBackoff.assertEquals(AssertWithBackoff.java:147)
        at gobblin.scheduler.JobConfigFileMonitorTest.testAddNewJobConfigFile(JobConfigFileMonitorTest.java:91)
```
Increased the timeout from 5000 ms to 7500 ms. The test also failed on Hudson, so this change should also prevent that from happening again.
LGTM.
LGTM
@zliu41 can you review?
LGTM other than above
Trivial change. Self-approving.
Trivial change. Self-approving.
It looks like the patch uses Java 8 features. Currently, Gobblin is Java 7-based.
Ah, right. Will fix.
Any chance that this can get done?  What is outstanding?
LGTM.
LGTM

Hey, thanks for catching this. It looks like we've missed the following section from the Pegasus doc: https://github.com/linkedin/rest.li/wiki/Gradle-build-integration#publishing-maven-artifacts . It looks similar to yours. What do you think about adding the "official" documentation?
LGTM.

I tried adding that last night and while the data-template jar was uploaded to artifactory, the empty jar was still there.  The layout would then be:

gobblin-rest-api-VERSION.jar                261 bytes
gobblin-rest-api-VERSION-sources.jar            261 bytes
gobblin-rest-api-VERSION-javadoc.jar            261 bytes
gobblin-rest-api-VERSION-data-template.jar  41 kilobytes

Im not confident that this would actually solve the problem because I haven't tested it.  In addition, it seems misleading that the jar, sources.jar and javadoc.jar are empty.
One comment. Other than that LGTM.
The build failure should be fixed by #548
Yeah, we'll restart working on that. Last thing I remember there were some strange errors with the version of Java 8 that was being used on Travis. We have to see if those are still there.

@kadaan can you have a look at https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/550 ? This generates two more artifacts gobblin-rest-api-data-template and gobblin-rest-api-rest-client . gobblin-rest-api.jar is empty because there is no code in src/main/java . The concern that I have about your PR is that if someone adds code under src/main/java , it will be dropped since gobblin-rest-api.jar gets overwritten.
LGTM
@liyinan926 can you review too?

@sahilTakiar in general it looks good. I noticed a few changes in API that may not work with the future plans for the library. Let's talk about these plans to make sure any changes made right now are compatible with them.
LGTM
LGTM

The build fails because of a dependency that cannot be found (https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/98180109/log.txt)

```
* What went wrong:
Could not resolve all dependencies for configuration ':gobblin-yarn:testCompile'.
> Could not find org.apache.calcite:calcite-core:0.9.2-incubating-SNAPSHOT.
  Required by:
      gobblin:gobblin-yarn:unspecified > gobblin:gobblin-core:unspecified > org.apache.hive:hive-exec:0.14.0
> Could not find org.apache.calcite:calcite-avatica:0.9.2-incubating-SNAPSHOT.
  Required by:
      gobblin:gobblin-yarn:unspecified > gobblin:gobblin-core:unspecified > org.apache.hive:hive-exec:0.14.0
```

Hive 0.14 uses datanucleus-core and datanucleus-rdbms version `3.2.10`.
When Gobblin used `4.0.5` I had to downgrade the version to avoid runtime errors in the Hive compactor, like:
`java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.datanucleus.util.Localiser.getInstance(Ljava/lang/String;Ljava/lang/ClassLoader;)Lorg/datanucleus/util/Localiser;`
Now `4.1.2` is set, but I guess the downgrading might still be needed.
@chavdar Is it necessary to put everything in the `gobblin.config.store.api`, for example, the custom exception classes `VersionDoesNotExistException`?
LGTM other than minor comments.
@ydai1124 The exception is part of the API so I tihnk it should be there. Any alternatives?
@chavdar No, if that is part of the API :).

@ibuenros updated based on comments and offline discussion
- Created a new utility class called `ConfigUtils` with a method `propertiesToConfig` which transforms a `Properties` object to a `Config` object and checks that no two keys are prefixes of each other (turns out the typesafe library already has an easy way of doing the check)
- Restored all usages of the `Config` object
- Moved usage of `rateUnit` and `durationUnit` to `MetricReportReporter` which is where it is specified in the builder
- The constructors for `KafkaReporter` and `OutputStreamReporter` now take in a `Builder` and `Config` object - I decided to leave the `Builder` parameter as removing it would require too much re-factoring and this PR is already long
Updated the PR with addressing the code review comments and adding three more factory methods to ConfigKeyPath .
Never mind, the factory methods need to be static and in the actual implementation.
@ibuenros comments addressed and build is now passing.
LGTM.

The test that fails has a 137 return code from its Gradle Test Executor. It could be that a specific test is failing because it's using up too much memory, in which case TravisCI SIGKILLS it (see: https://discuss.gradle.org/t/gradle-travis-ci/11928/3). I'll try to fix the test to use less memory.
@sahilTakiar @zliu41 can you review?
@chavdar: Recreated this PR, removing the fix for #545 that you guys did differently. Can you review again?
LGTM

LGTM.

By the way, my fix didn't work completely -- we are generating the new artifacts but the dependencies are not captured correctly. We are working with the rest.li team to figure this out.
Well, if a stopgap is needed, my fix did work.  The issue at hand is we can't build against gobblin unless #545 is fixed.
LGTM.
Superseded by the squash commit in https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/560

@chavdar It seems TravisCI is killing certain test processes (possibly because they are consuming too many resources.) I just significantly reduced the memory usage of some tests, but they still continue to get killed. Can you think of anything we can do to debug or sidestep this issue?
LGTM.
LGTM
LGTM.
